For anyone trying to make sense of Musk having Twitter engineers print out their code and show it to Tesla engineers… my view is we don’t need to look far to see what is happening.

Elon doesn’t like to pay severance. From my coverage in Tesla’s secret layoffs in @Pragmatic_Eng:

photo.alt:
Tesla is terminating ~10% of its workforce and making it look like these are performance-related layoffs. But it’s actually a mass layoff happening in one go. I talked with three software engineers who all exited on Wednesday, 14 June. The setup was the same in all cases:

The manager of the employee read from a script when terminating the employment, saying they were terminating based on performance.
These meetings were done in secret, in the sense only the affected employee and their manager knew of the layoff.
Employees had five business days to accept the severance package, which is one week only. Compare this with both Klarna and Coinbase’s offerings of at least 14 weeks-worth of severance.
Managers were not allowed to say the layoffs were en masse; to do so risked their own position.
